content.text: Latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI) is a state of persistent immune response to stimulation by Mycobacterium tuberculosis antigens without evidence of clinically manifest active TB. Individuals with LTBI are asymptomatic and not infectious.

diagnosticTestData.name: Tuberculin Skin Test (TST)
diagnosticTestData.interpretation: Induration size is interpreted based on risk factors. A positive test indicates TB infection but does not distinguish between latent and active disease.

diagnosticTestData.name: Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs)
diagnosticTestData.interpretation: Measures T-cell release of interferon-gamma in response to M. tuberculosis antigens. Like TST, a positive test does not distinguish between latent and active TB.

procedureData.name: Chest X-ray
procedureData.indication: To rule out active pulmonary TB in all persons diagnosed with LTBI.
procedureData.timing: Required before starting treatment for LTBI.

content.text: Treatment Regimens for Latent TB Infection

regimenData.notes: Also referred to as 3HR. A preferred short-course regimen.
Also referred to as 3HP. Administered as once-weekly therapy for 12 weeks. Not recommended for pregnant women or children <2 years old.
Also referred to as 4R. A preferred short-course regimen, especially for those with contraindications to isoniazid.
6H or 9H. Longer duration regimens, now less favored than shorter-course options due to lower completion rates and higher toxicity risk.
